And if you say the word
 I could stay with you

It’s not immediately obvious, and it’s part of the charm of the song, that the whole song is actually a marriage proposal, from a young man to his intended life-partner. The “word” referred to here is “yes”, and the big question crops up again in the closing lines: “Give me your answer, fill in a form, Mine for evermore”. The form of course being the wedding contract.

This song was written by McCartney when he was a teen and most likely revived due to the fact that his father turned 64 in the same year the recording was made.

The inspiration most likely came from Paul speculating about his own age, he wrote the song at 16 which is precisely ¼ of 64.

 On May 17, 2006, Paul and his then wife, Heather Mills, separated, finalizing the divorce in 2008. McCartney turned 64 on June 18, 2006, so the answer to his musical question with regards to Mills, would be no.

Sir George Martin worked with the Beatles for more than 25 years (including remasters). He guided them and acted as a mentor carefully listening to their sessions and offering structured advice. Many even consider him to be like a 5th Beatle. He was knighted in 1996 for his lifetime of contribution to the arts.
[Verse 1]

This song was originally intended to be released as the B-side of “Strawberry Fields Forever” and George Martin sincerely regrets not doing so:

The idea of a double a-side came from me and Brian, really… He came to me and said, ‘I must have a really great single. What have you got?’ I said, ‘Well, I’ve got three tracks – and two of them are the best tracks they’ve ever made. We could put them together and make a smashing single.’ We did, and it was a smashing single – but it was also a dreadful mistake. We would have sold far more and got higher in the charts if we had issued one of those with, say, When I’m Sixty-Four on the back.

Send me a postcard, drop me a line
 Stating point of view

A long time ago, in the 20th century, before the Internet, smartphones, and the sharing of photos; people used to send each other postcards from places they would visit. Many can be found in antique shows, or museums.

Grandchildren on your knee
 Vera, Chuck, and Dave

McCartney has plenty of grandchildren, with names including Reiley, Bailey, Miller, Sam, Sid, Elliott, and Arthur. However there is no Vera, Chuck, or Dave, at least yet.

The Beatles have always had fun naming their fictional characters, like many of the others these ones have their origin in pure spontaneity, a Lennon remarked:

When I’m Sixty-Four was something Paul wrote in the Cavern days. We just stuck a few more words on it like ‘grandchildren on your knee’ and ‘Vera, Chuck and Dave’. It was just one of those ones that he’d had, that we’ve all got, really; half a song. And this was just one that was quite a hit with us. We used to do them when the amps broke down, just sing it on the piano.

I could be handy mending a fuse
 When your lights have gone
 You can knit a sweater by the fireside
 Sunday mornings go for a ride

This verse encapsulates the appeal of the song. It is written from the hopeful naivete of a young amorous boy (McCartney was only 16 when he first wrote the song!) and therefore represents the timeless longing of ideal domestic love.

The lines come off as quaint and borderline adorable representing a slow yet enjoyable and active existence of two lovers grown old together.
